body:
I was reading through the Ruqqus Policies section and encountered a few which I am unsure about how to interpret them, their scope or other aspect. Some seems to me as a contradiction - allowed after asking admins, but not according to the written rules. I tried to search for previous posts regarding this, but I don't know how to search in one guild (`tos +ruqqus` returned 0 results). It's also entirely possible I misunderstood some clauses (English is not my native language, I would guess even a lot of native speakers will have troubles with legal English).

Please, don't get me wrong - I want Ruqqus to succeed, to prevail and grow. I already donated a lot of time and effort to improve the user experience (RuqES) and help others on Discord. Don't take this post as trying to smear or otherwise harm Ruqqus, this is meant to clear confusion, misconceptions, to discuss about current policies and how to, if at all, improve them. I would bet sooner or later opposition will try to attack Ruqqus in some form and it's better to try to anticipate problems, discuss solutions and prevent potential problems before they become real ones.

# Account Access

> You will not provide a third party with your ruqqus.com password or two-factor authentication codes.

This seems to me that 3rd party applications (e.g. Android, iOS, desktop clients) are forbidden. But admins wrote multiple times that (at least Android apps) are ok. Maybe it wouldn't be a reason for ban, but rather a warning for users to not share their login info? Or maybe it will be enforced when public API arrives? (I hope public API won't be overly restrictive.)

# Intellectual Property

> You grant Ruqqus a permanent, worldwide, and irrevocable license to store, modify, copy, distribute, and distribute modifications of, all content that you submit to or upload to Ruqqus, including any creative works. Additionally, you grant Ruqqus a permanent, worldwide, and irrevocable license to sublicense these same rights to Ruqqus's service providers.

I don't like `modify`, `permanent` and  `irrevocable`. Shouldn't user be able to revoke license after for example deleting their account? Or just deleting their post?

I realize `modify` is probably because of formatting, nevertheless I can't stop myself from thinking about how R*ddit admin was modifying other user's post. I didn't see any clause about admins stating they will not do such action here. Maybe it's expected to be covered under "Without Censorship" in the home page title?

# Acceptable Use

> You will not use ruqqus.com as a means to support any other website or service without written permission by Ruqqus.

What does this mean? Can I create a guild (without written permission) with content related to my (hypothetical) company? Or a product (e.g. software, site, game)?

# Digital Safety

> You may not upload to, embed within, or link out from ruqqus.com:
> ...
> URL shorteners

While as a developer I can understand why one might forbid them, as a user I would like to see them allowed (e.g. stats are nice). Also I would like to see a definition of URL shortener. Because technically for example `youtu.be` falls into this category, yet I don't think it is forbidden. Is any redirect on any server (via e.g. 3xx, meta tag or JS) with URL shorter than target's considered a shortener? I wouldn't think so (because then `http://ruqqus.com` could be considered shortener, since it redirects to `https://ruqqus.com/` [notice added `s` and `/`]), but I may be wrong.

# User Safety

> You may not use ruqqus.com to do any of the following:
> ...
> Threaten or intimidate other users

This doesn't seem very "free speechy" to me. Also it is very vague and in my opinion could serve as a free ban reason. Is writing "f*** off" an intimidation? What about "stop commenting or I'll ban you" when in position of power (GM, by ban is meant kick from a guild)? I think at least the second one technically fits the definition `to force into or deter from some action by inducing fear`, but I don't see why it should be forbidden.

> Solicit, collect, or publish personal information, either yours or another individual's

I am not sure why `collect` should be forbidden. Since the information was made public, why is it against rules? Can a user be banned if they take a screenshot of a doxx (and don't post it on ruqqus.com)? Can people be banned for off-site behavior? I hope not, I really disliked how Blizzard banned someone from their game over a tweet which I believe didn't even relate to the game.

# IRL Safety

> Incite, plan, or execute unlawful or violent activity

I don't know, wouldn't some naughty practices where a "victim" consents to suffer or be hurt also fall under this? It feels to me it should be allowed on a free speech platform. And that's only when I go with more, I guess classic, definition of violence. I found on MW under definition of violence this:

> vehement feeling or expression

Maybe further specifying what a "violent activity" means wouldn't hurt.

# Third-party Service Providers

Probably a bit off topic, but some of the services listed do not support free speech, e.g. Mailgun banned Gab and I believe Cloud Flare did ban some news site for political reasons as well.

I hope admins have backups in place, meaning Ruqqus is not tightly integrated with 3rd party via its API to just one service, e.g. Mailgun, but there is support in code (currently inactive) for other service(s) to quickly switch if/when the first service decides to ban us.

title: Questions about ToS and other policies

body:
I can't really talk about some of the technicalities for the legal stuff, being neither American nor a lawyer, but with regards to the two sections:

> You may not use ruqqus.com to do any of the following: ... Threaten or intimidate other users

> Incite, plan, or execute unlawful or violent activity

, Ruqqus only guarantees free speech up to what is protected by America's first amendment. Those things have been [found to not be covered](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_free_speech_exceptions#CITEREFVolokh2008), and as such are not guaranteed on Ruqqus

body:
> Account access

This one means don't have a shared account, because there's a lot of bot farms that like to sell accounts.

> Intellectual Property

I think you're misinterpreting what they mean here. It's not about editing your posts, it's so Disney and/or butthurt SJW content creators don't sue Ruqqus for "MUH COPYRIGHT" because someone dared to discuss one of their ideas without their permission. Honestly it's stupid that Ruqqus should even need your permission in the first place for that, especially since they only need this to host your content.

> Acceptable Use

I don't think the admins are out to stop discussing other services, but doing so could potentially lead to loss of revenue for them and right now they're not exactly swimming in cash.

> Digital Safety

The reason for banning embedding is the same as the Acceptable Use clause. If you embed an image from Ruqqus, it costs money for the servers to return the image to viewers, but since it doesn't actually bring up the Ruqqus website they also don't gain any money.

> User Safety

Ruqqus has to ban harassment because it's actually illegal almost everywhere, even in the United States.

> IRL Safety

Inciting unlawful activity is illegal. Again, Ruqqus has no choice but to ban illegal speech.

> Third-party Service Providers

They need this protection as they suffer countless DDoS attacks among others, and at the moment they are too preoccupied with other things to develop their own protection mechanisms.

> You will not provide a third party with your ruqqus.com password or two-factor authentication codes.

This seems to me that 3rd party applications (e.g. Android, iOS, desktop clients) are forbidden. But admins wrote multiple times that (at least Android apps) are ok. Maybe it wouldn't be a reason for ban, but rather a warning for users to not share their login info? Or maybe it will be enforced when public API arrives? (I hope public API won't be overly restrictive.)

# Intellectual Property

> You grant Ruqqus a permanent, worldwide, and irrevocable license to store, modify, copy, distribute, and distribute modifications of, all content that you submit to or upload to Ruqqus, including any creative works. Additionally, you grant Ruqqus a permanent, worldwide, and irrevocable license to sublicense these same rights to Ruqqus's service providers.

I don't like `modify`, `permanent` and  `irrevocable`. Shouldn't user be able to revoke license after for example deleting their account? Or just deleting their post?

I realize `modify` is probably because of formatting, nevertheless I can't stop myself from thinking about how R*ddit admin was modifying other user's post. I didn't see any clause about admins stating they will not do such action here. Maybe it's expected to be covered under "Without Censorship" in the home page title?

# Acceptable Use

> You will not use ruqqus.com as a means to support any other website or service without written permission by Ruqqus.

What does this mean? Can I create a guild (without written permission) with content related to my (hypothetical) company? Or a product (e.g. software, site, game)?

# Digital Safety

> You may not upload to, embed within, or link out from ruqqus.com:
> ...
> URL shorteners

While as a developer I can understand why one might forbid them, as a user I would like to see them allowed (e.g. stats are nice). Also I would like to see a definition of URL shortener. Because technically for example `youtu.be` falls into this category, yet I don't think it is forbidden. Is any redirect on any server (via e.g. 3xx, meta tag or JS) with URL shorter than target's considered a shortener? I wouldn't think so (because then `http://ruqqus.com` could be considered shortener, since it redirects to `https://ruqqus.com/` [notice added `s` and `/`]), but I may be wrong.

# User Safety

> You may not use ruqqus.com to do any of the following:
> ...
> Threaten or intimidate other users

This doesn't seem very "free speechy" to me. Also it is very vague and in my opinion could serve as a free ban reason. Is writing "f*** off" an intimidation? What about "stop commenting or I'll ban you" when in position of power (GM, by ban is meant kick from a guild)? I think at least the second one technically fits the definition `to force into or deter from some action by inducing fear`, but I don't see why it should be forbidden.

> Solicit, collect, or publish personal information, either yours or another individual's

I am not sure why `collect` should be forbidden. Since the information was made public, why is it against rules? Can a user be banned if they take a screenshot of a doxx (and don't post it on ruqqus.com)? Can people be banned for off-site behavior? I hope not, I really disliked how Blizzard banned someone from their game over a tweet which I believe didn't even relate to the game.

# IRL Safety

> Incite, plan, or execute unlawful or violent activity

I don't know, wouldn't some naughty practices where a "victim" consents to suffer or be hurt also fall under this? It feels to me it should be allowed on a free speech platform. And that's only when I go with more, I guess classic, definition of violence. I found on MW under definition of violence this:

> vehement feeling or expression

Maybe further specifying what a "violent activity" means wouldn't hurt.

# Third-party Service Providers

Probably a bit off topic, but some of the services listed do not support free speech, e.g. Mailgun banned Gab and I believe Cloud Flare did ban some news site for political reasons as well.

I hope admins have backups in place, meaning Ruqqus is not tightly integrated with 3rd party via its API to just one service, e.g. Mailgun, but there is support in code (currently inactive) for other service(s) to quickly switch if/when the first service decides to ban us.
